[[Beleriand]] (during the [[War of Wrath]]) | affiliation=[[Manwë]] | language= | birth= | birthlocation= | rule= | death= | deathlocation= | age= | notablefor=Leading the [[Host of Valinor]] in the [[War of Wrath]] | house= | parentage= | siblings= | spouse= | children= | gender=Male | height= | hair= | eyes= | clothing= | weapons=[[Sword of Manwë]] (during the [[War of Wrath]]) | steed= }}
{{Quote|Eönwë, the banner-bearer and herald of [[Manwë]], whose might in arms is surpassed by none in [[Arda]].|''[[The Silmarillion]]'', "[[Valaquenta]]"}}
'''Eönwë''' was the banner-bearer and herald of [[Manwë]], and chief of the [[Maiar]] along with [[Ilmarë]].{{S|IIc}} == History == === First Age === [[File:Mysilvergreen - Eonwe.jpg|thumb|200px|left|"Eonwe" by [[:Category:Images by Mysilvergreen|Mysilvergreen]]]] When [[Eärendil]] reached the shores of [[Aman]], it was Eönwë who first greeted him and summoned him to come before the Powers of [[Arda]]. When [[Manwë]] decided to heed the appeal, he gave [[Sword of Manwë|his sword]] to Eönwë{{WJ|Last}}, p. 246 and sent him to Middle-earth to fight the [[War of Wrath]], leading the [[Vanyar]].{{S|Earendil}} It is said that it was Eönwë who overthrew Morgoth.{{PM|Akallabeth}} When [[Morgoth]] was defeated Eönwë played a key role in the aftermath. He took the two remaining [[Silmarils]] and held them for safekeeping, but when the two remaining [[Sons of Fëanor]] stole them and fled, Eönwë did not allow them to be slain. Afterwards, [[Sauron]] paid obeisance to Eönwë and abjured all of his evil deeds. But because Eönwë had not the power to pardon Sauron, he commanded him to return to Aman to receive Manwë's judgement. Unwilling to receive humiliation and sentencing, when Eönwë left Sauron hid in [[Middle-earth]] and fell back into evil.{{S|Rings}} === Second Age === At the dawn of the [[Second Age]], Eönwë came among the three faithful houses of the [[Edain]] and taught them many things; and they were blessed with wisdom and power and longer [[mortality|life-spans]]. These Edain eventually became the [[High Men]] of [[Númenor]].{{S|Akallabeth}} == Etymology == {{Pronounce|Eonwe.mp3|Ardamir}} The name ''Eönwë'' is [[Quenya]] in form.{{HM|Guide}}, entry 'Eonwe'{{webcite|website=Arda|articleurl=http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/quen-eng.htm|articlename=Quettaparma|authorname=[[Helge Fauskanger]]}} However the ancient [[Loremasters]] knew no [[Elvish]] etymology of the name, suggesting that it is probably of [[Valarin]] origin.{{WJ|Author}}; note that the original text discusses the character's earlier name, "Fionwe", which [[Christopher Tolkien]] considers a mistake.{{webcite|website=Arda|articleurl=http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/Valarin.htm|articlename=Valarin|authorname=[[Helge Fauskanger]]}} See also the [[Quenya]] ending ''[[-wë]]''.{{MR|Myths}} == Other versions of the legendarium == In the earlier conceptions of the [[legendarium]], Eönwë was envisioned as the son of Manwë, but as the concept of the [[Valarindi]] (i.e. the Children of the Valar) was abandoned, he was turned into Manwë's herald instead.{{LT1|II}}, p. 58 In some versions Eönwë was the one who would kill Morgoth for his love for [[Arien]] (previously named ''Urwendi''), instead of [[Túrin]].{{LT1|IX}}, p. 219 In ''[[The Earliest 'Silmarillion']]'', he was the son of [[Tulcas]].{{SM|2}}{{rp|§17}} In both early and later versions of the ''[[Akallabêth]]'' it is revealed that it was Fionwë/Eönwë who overthrew Morgoth at the end of the War of Wrath, but [[Christopher Tolkien]] removed this reference in the published ''[[Silmarillion]]'', believing that his father intended to diminish his role; however, Christopher Tolkien later felt the omission may have been an error on his part.{{rp|143}} === Earlier names === In earlier works, such as ''[[The Book of Lost Tales]]'', his name was ''Fionwë'' which translates to "Son", from [[Qenya]] ''[[fion]]''.{{LT1|Appendix}} This possibly alludes to his previous conception as the son of Manwë. His other early name, ''Urion'', means "He of the [[Sun]]", from ''[[ur]]'' ("the Sun"), ''uru'' ("fire") or ''urin'' ("blazing"), + the masculine suffix ''[[-ion]]''.{{PE|Eldarin}} == See also == *[[Nornorë]] {{references}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eonwe}} {{ainur}} [[Category:Characters in The Book of Lost Tales]] [[Category:Characters in The Silmarillion]] [[Category:First Age characters]] [[Category:Maiar]] [[Category:Pronounced articles]] [[Category:Quenya names]] [[Category:Rulers in Aman]] [[Category:Second Age characters]] [[Category:Valarindi]] [[de:Eonwe]] [[fr:encyclo/personnages/ainur/maiar/eoenwe]] [[fi:Eönwë]]
